solution_01_data_basics/05_spread/01_get_range_v2

(ANS=4.56)

video

To determine the range by hand, you subtract the minimum value from the maximum value. You could first sort all the data. \[\text{sort}(\mathbf{x}) = 45.43, 47.08, 47.67, 48.08, 48.93, 49.28, 49.59, 49.80, 49.93, 49.95, 49.97, 49.99 \] Determine the minimum. \[\text{min}(\mathbf{x}) = 45.43 \] Determine the maximum. \[\text{max}(\mathbf{x}) = 49.99\] Take the difference. \[\text{range}(\mathbf{x}) = \text{max}(\mathbf{x})-\text{min}(\mathbf{x}) = 49.99-45.43 = 4.56 \]

Spreadsheet

In a spreadsheet, you can use the MIN function and MAX function.


You can see a solution spreadsheet here.

R

In R, you can use the MIN and MAX functions.

# First, get the csv into the working directory... then...
data = read.csv("get_range.csv")
x = data$x
range = max(x)-min(x)
print(range)
## [1] 4.56
